awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: Why is the High-Latitude Ionosphere More Variable in January than in July?
awd_abstract_narration:
With humanity continuing to explore last frontiers of the new Arctic and Antarctic, polar nations invest heavily in improving navigation satellite coverage of this region. In this context, the ionized portion of the upper atmosphere (ionosphere) at polar latitudes represents an important piece of the puzzle, since it is the medium through which the satellite radio signal travels and since it is known to contain strong disturbances. This award provides support for a comprehensive investigation into unexpected plasma density enhancements at polar latitudes called sporadic-F. The focus of the investigation is on the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) observations of sporadic-F. Navigation satellites often experience degradation of radio signal quality and sporadic F has been demonstrated to be one of the leading causes. Opening of Arctic to shipping traffic as the ice cap melts and an ever-increasing number of transpolar flights make this investigation particularly timely due to its potential to characterize occurrence and identify mechanisms for GNSS signal loss. 

This investigation will validate a recent set of satellite observations that fly in the face of conventional wisdom and past expectations based on decades of northern hemisphere data analysis. The validation will utilize ground-based observations in both hemispheres and first-principles modeling. It is well-known that sporadic-F is controlled by magnetospheric forcings (convection and precipitation), and it has been hypothesized that thermospheric variations may also be important. Therefore, new insights into the characteristics of those systems (magnetosphere and thermosphere) are expected. To aid in mapping and understanding dynamic high-latitude plasma flows, the state-of-the-art Lagrangian coherent structure analysis code will be used and developed. This work has the potential to transform the understanding of a phenomenon that has been the subject of extensive study since its discovery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated a puzzling phenomenon occurring in the geospace region that surrounds Earth, addressing the question: "Why is the High-Latitude Ionosphere More Variable in January than in July?"

Patches of plasma are frequently observed in the northern ionosphere in winter and at equinox. These are believed to be made up of dense photo-ionized plasma transported into the caps from the subauroral dayside, under the action of the magnetospheric convection pattern. This phenomenon was previously believed to be absent during summer, because local photo-ionization in the polar region "swamped" any plasma convected in from lower latitudes at that time of year.

Surprisingly, satellite and now groundbased observations indicate this pattern is effectively reversed in the southern hemisphere, with many patches observed in southern summer and very few seen in southern winter. In both hemispheres, the minimum of patch detections occurs in June and July, and so the local seasonal behavior is reversed. This pattern is believed to be responsible for an important form of space weather, as it matches the reported GPS outages onboard satellites in low Earth orbit. 

This investigation corroborated the only previous report of this phenomenon, which was highly controversial at the time. Additionally we published a new technique for observing the Antarctic ionosphere, and performed simulations answering the science question. The surprising annual pattern at high latitudes is in part due to a global asymmetry present in the ionosphere, where ionization levels are on average 30% higher in January than in July. Additionally, the neutral upper atmosphere plays an important role, causing especially long plasma lifetimes in northern winter and relatively short lifetimes in southern winter. In the long term we expect these findings will contribute to the predictability of the high-latitude ionosphere, relevant to several technological applications in development there.
